channel.title: Missing link shows itself?
channel.description:
[i][COLOR='Silver']"Remarkably well preserved for a two-million-year-old fossil, this child's skull belongs to Australopithecus Sediba, a previously unknown species of ape-like creature that may have been a direct ancestor of modern humans, according to a new study in Science."[/i]
This discovery might just be the "missing link" we've been trying to find for so long. The link that pretty much sets the evolution of ape-to-man in stone (no pun intended). While we've pretty much come to terms with the whole "humans and apes, all the same"-idea, there was still a piece of the puzzle missing. This discovery is a perfect balance between ape-like features and human-like features.
[url]https://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2010/04/photogalleries/100408-australopithecus-sediba-human-species-fossil-pictures/[/url]

item.title: Missing link shows itself?
item.dc:creator: Note-anator
item.description:
You know… the problem with articles like this, is that they use the term “Missing link” - What missing link? What exactly is missing? The smoking gun that is the final word on Humans desending from a common ancestor where both apes and humans split from an evolutionary common? What kind of nonsense is that? The evidence is beyond robust already. It is beyond any credible scientific scrutiny. (Other than, if there are minor corrections that need to be made - which speaks well of science, because they are always after the facts)

How much evidence needs to be collected before this nonsense stops? They are ALL missing links. Every damn one of them. It merely depends on where you look in the time line, and which branch.

There is enough confusioin with this issue already, without the media adding to it. The goofy part, is the next find, will be hailed as the missing link… How many missing links are there exacty?

Would it not be better to say “Another fossil has been found that fits nicely into the already robust evidence that we have concerning human evolution”. But NNNNNoooooooooooo the Dumb-ass media has to go for contraversial angle, thus prolonging the confusion.

What missing link?

Read full topic

item.title: Missing link shows itself?

item.description:
The article even refutes claims that it would be a missing link. The fossil is younger than some hominids.

This is closer to a missing link.

Read full topic

item.title: Missing link shows itself?
item.dc:creator: danielsangeo
item.description:
It’s true. The missing link between 1 and 10 is 5. But that opens two missing links between 1 and 5 and 5 and 10. So, you find 3.5 and 7.5. But now that opens FOUR missing links (1 and 3.5, 3.5 and 5, 5 and 7.5, and 7.5 and 10). And so on and so forth. Eventually, you’ll be looking for the “missing link” between parent and child.

Read full topic

item.title: Missing link shows itself?
item.dc:creator: bur
item.description:
“THE” missing link does not exist. For every fossil showing a transition between humans and earlier apes there are two more “missing links.”

Read full topic

item.title: Missing link shows itself?
item.dc:creator: Mr.Shadow
item.description:
Comrade Tiki:

i should trust your opinion because of your clarity and precision.

Alright, maybe I exegarate a bit, but my point still stands. It’s almost like they say this with every primate fossil they find. It’s just ridiculous to me that they keep on saying this without any kind of reason to say that at that point. If you find a fossil and research it for maybe a week or 2, are you gonna say by then already that it might be the ancestor of insertprehistoricmegafaunahere? No, because that takes more then just 2 weeks.

Read full topic
